title: Makerbot Replicator 1 Z Axis Guide Rod End Stabilizing Cap replacement.

This is a Gnome keyboard key for your FSF-certified Libreboot X200 laptop - a customized version of the Lenovo ThinkPad X200 modified to respect your freedom (read the following article for more info: http://www.fsf.org/news/libreboot-x200-laptop-now-fsf-certified-to-respect-your-freedom). Some Lenovo X200 keyboards might have different hinge styles. This print is designed for model L39 (small key). Attach the button with caution - the fixations could easily break during the assembly.

Box holder for turntable Technics sl1210 mk2

This is my floating "Treasure Island" for the #MakeItFloat Challenge. It is designed to allow burying a treasure (coins) inside !

Video : https://youtu.be/ma-QDHCmzo8

Experiments:
My first design was a simple hemisphere (like a bowl) and coins attached at the bottom (I wanted it to be as simple as possible). It was a total fail and I learned two things for floating/ partially submersible objects :

  • the air must be captured inside the object and should have no way to get out under pressure (the hemisphere was not stable and when the air began to get out it returned and sank instantaneously)
  • All the added weight (coins) shall be placed on the vertical axis where the gravitiy center is located for best stability.
    My final design is stable and doesn't sink ;-)

Technical specifications :
Designed with OpenSCAD (http://www.openscad.org/)
Filament used for printing : PLA 1.75mm (yellow, black and green)
Printer : Prusa I3 Hephestos
Coin size : all currency will fit up to 32mm diameter
Maximum treasure weight for floating : 80g (not stable if heavier)
Island weight (without treasure) : 100g

Tips:

  • You can place any kind of treasure inside the island, it is not limited to coins (but make sure it is waterproof if you want to put the island into water)
  • The island can also be used for hiding objects (such as keys, usb drive, ...) as it looks like a simple decorative object when placed on a shelf.

Printing (using Cura):

  • print the island base (island_v2.stl) (Support type : none, Platform adhesion type : none)

  • print the tree trunk (trunk.stl) (Support type : none, Platform adhesion type : Brim)

  • print the tree leaves (leaves_v2.stl) : rotate the leaves 180° so that they are printed upside down. Print four leaves with scale respectively set to 80%, 90%, 100% and 110% (Support type : none, Platform adhesion type : Brim)

  • [optional] print the coin (coin.stl) (Support type : none, Platform adhesion type : none)

Assembly:

  • The bottom of the tree trunk is flat so you have to trim it so that it has the same curve as the top of the island base

  • Glue the tree trunk to the island base (there is a pin on top of the island base and a hole at the bottom of the tree trunk so that it can be placed in the center)

  • Attach the leaves on top of each branch. For this I didn't use glue but Velcro tape so that it is easy to adjust the leaves.

  • [optional] Add a cross to mark the place where the treasure was buried so that the island looks nicer. I used two small parts of red tape for this.

Usage:

  • Place your treasure (coins) inside the hole on the bottom of the island and use the printed coin if necessary to close the hole (look at the pictures for an overview of the process)

  • place the island into water and watch it float ;-)

Note : if the island is not stable or tends to fall on its side, try to reduce the weight of the treasure (remove some coins).

remixed_from.author: chastavro
remixed_from.title: XYZ Da Vinci 1.0 X Axis Belt Tensioner

title: Davinci X belt manual tensioner with bearings

description.text:
The standard item has a spring and a pathetic screw to keep the tension on the belt. I found the screw would tire and then the belt would loosen under load as the spring let it go.

This is a remix of the belt tensioner http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:805215 that uses 2 x MR63ZZ (3x6x2.5mm) ball bearings mounted on the stock pulley and the original spring.

This version uses a 20mm M6 bolt through the end, it's much easier to fit - Simply loosen the bolt right off, push it all the way in, slot the idler pulley + bearings in on the belt and do the bolt up until it sounds like a bass string when plucked!

This version with bearings is much smoother than the stock item.

I did a version with a captive M6 nut, but it's much more difficult to fit, the thread ramps in the hole work just as solidly and help stop the bolt undoing.
print it on a raft with a solid infill

comments.text:
Just fitted one of these, excellent idea and the most effective tensioner mod yet !
I fitted a nut to mine for extra security using a hot soldering iron to heat the nut and push it into the area around the hole for the bolt.
This is the tightest I've ever been able to get the belt on the x axis. Can't recommend it highly enough.
Can't quite understand why it hasn't had more downloads ??
comments.author: scobo

comments.text: Just wanted to comment that I had printed this out a long time ago on my 1.0 but never needed it on that printer.  I was printing on my fairly new (3 months old) Pro tonight and before I went to bed I decided to check on the printer because it was printing a fairly long and complex job.  What I found was a mess with a glob of filament stuck to the print head and the x axis belt laying on the print bed and the stock tensioner in pieces.  Glad I decided to check on the printer, I would have had a real mess in the morning.  Took me about 30 minutes to clean up the printer, snap some pictures of the broken part and email XYZ with a support request and then I remembered printing this part out a while back.  I pulled it out of my parts bag, stuck some bearings on my pulley and had it back up and running in no time.  Works great.  Thanks!

title: RepRap Darwin Y axis bearing clamp

description.text: This variation on the Y axis bearing housing allows a 22mm 608Z "sk8er" bearing to be used on the Y axis drive shaft. This means the standard 8mm steel drive rod can be used but without the need to file a flat along its entire length. Alternatively, a threaded rod can be used, but attachment of gears using M8 nuts & washers is left as an exercise to the diligent researcher (I'm looking at you Graeme :).

Print. Poke captive nut into oblong hole. Clamp onto Z axis strut using M5 bolt or grub screw passing through captive nut. Hold the other side in position on an M8 threaded support using M8 nuts and washers. Arrange Y axis so that the bearing is pushed into the housing and don't squash the bearing with the M8 nuts!
If you print it a little tight, warm it up to get the bearing in. If it's a little loose, just wrap the outer edge of the bearing in PTFE tape.

comments.text: Absolutely brilliant work vik. title: Best ever Can/bottle cooler for Jeep Wrangler air conditioner vent

description.text:
[Updated Sep 14, 2015, see below]

There are two versions of this cooler, both works very well on my 2001 Wrangler:

RED - A bit larger on the outside as it holds the bottle in an angle to keep it away from the dashboard and the audio / navigation screen.

PURPLE - looks slimmer but has the same capacity, hold the bottle as close as possible to the dashboard and therefore may interfere when in front of a touch screen.

Personally I prefer the red version as it is not interfering with my touch screen.

The third part of the Red version is an optional bridge you need to glue in place in order to control the airflow and keep the bottle in the middle of the holder.

Apart from the four holes (for screws holding the container part) which only exists on the PURPLE version, the two Vent parts are identical.

Both versions can be used on center or side (window) vents. On center vents the holders are held with a latch preventing them from accidentally turning with vent’s bearing.

Sep 14, 2015 - Added a vent part that has a small bump to help "click" the part in the vent nozzle and prevent it from sliding out when driving off-road.
RED Bottle Cooler Part B - Vent with bump.stl

description.text: I've been developing ways to use 3d powder printing to make air powered robots that have no hard moving parts. Using procedural modeling I can create rapid iterations, incremental designs, and inexpensive prototypes with a simple set of tools. Find more details at - http://bit.ly/softrobots You can see video of this design in action here - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EkPeF-sYQ-0 This is an early prototype of a trefoil tentacle. There are three hollow ribbed volumes inside this tentacle that control its motion. It is controlled through a Processing interface and an Arduino switching a bank of solenoid valves using a simple Darlington transistor. You can grab the code here - http://forums.adafruit.com/viewtopic.php?f=25&t=36579 and a detailed tutorial on how to build your own here http://learn.adafruit.com/silicone-robo-tentacle?view=all This whole project has been made possible by the folks over at http://viridis3d.com especially Jim Bredt. They've been very generous in letting me use their machines and helping me figure out solutions to the material science challenges involved in this kind of work. They're awesome.

Print out three copies of the shell component on a powder printer. This method would also work on a DLP or Objet printer. Print one copy of the block mold. Infiltrate all the parts with an epoxy resin. Wax all the surfaces that will touch silicone to make sure no rubber penetrates into the matrix. If this happens it's guaranteed to lock your mold and you'll have to start again from the beginning. Pour silicone into the block mold up to its rim. When it's cured, remove it. Use an xacto to split the rubber on the overhang down at one end of the mold. Once you've removed the silicone, flip it over and cast wax into the voids. Laser cut the alignment jig out of .11" material and assemble it. This will help align and center the wax core. Take all the wax pieces out of your silicone mold and assemble them with the help of the alignment jig. Use a soldering iron to melt the wax between the seams of the tall wax pieces and the base. Bolt the 3 mold shells together with 1/4"-20 screws and insert the wax core. Pour a slow curing silicone into the holes at the top of the mold. This mold doesn't contain a sprue, so be careful not to pour too quickly and overflow the mold. For a bubble free casting, I recommending putting this whole assembly into a vacuum chamber, but a low viscosity silicone will do a pretty good job all by itself. When the silicone is cured you can take the mold apart and pull out the wax core. If it doesn't come out cleanly (mine took a lot of fiddling to finally eject) boil the tentacle in soapy water until the wax melts out. Laser cut the stand out of 1/8" material. Run 3/8" tubing through the trefoil shaped piece, leaving about 1" sticking through it. Stick the tubing into the tentacle, and adhere it to the base using silicone caulk (I use Sil-Poxy). I fastened everything together with luer fittings, and controlled the tentacle using an arduino PWM-ing a few solenoid valves. You can see my code here http://forums.adafruit.com/viewtopic.php?f=25&t=36579 For more details on the process and materials involved, you can look at some photo documentation of a tentacle coming together here - https://secure.flickr.com/photos/gianteye/sets/72157632460625971/ and you can find my complete writeups on the entire soft robotics project here - http://bit.ly/softrobots

title: Body for Raspberry Pi Camera with Lens Adapter

description.text: This is a body lased from 3mm MDF that protects the Raspberry Pi camera board PCB and also allows to attach 37mm Lenses (e.g. Wide-Angle, Tele or Macro Lenses from Lensbaby). It also has a screw at the bottom to attach a tripod and an optional button at the top that could be attached to one of the rpi's GPIO ports.

For attaching the lenses I used an old 37 mm filter (from which the glass was removed) and that is fixed between the two front panels. Depending on what kind of filter you use you might have to adjust the size of the two front holes  
You will also need 4 small 2mm screws to attach the PCB to the small holding panel - I found mine in my scrapbox.  
The screw for the tripod attachment I harvested from an old cheap camera.

Pequeño Cubo de calibración de 20 mm, con las esquinas redondeadas, y con los puntos del típico dado de puntos.Hemos impreso uno en PLA a 195ºC, 0,2 de re4solución, espesor de paredes de 1,2 mm e infill del 15% a 70 mms en una Prusa I3 Hephestos.
El segundo dado ha sido metiéndole trozos de PLA (algunos flexibles) de forma poco ortodoxa, es decir, alimentando el extrusor sin hacer parada y de forma continua. El resultado es regular, pero queda divertido!
Pongo tambien el fichero en DWG por si alguien quiere modificarlo.
Tengo una versión de dado con letras, y sin matar esquinas, que también va bien para calibrar. Pongo los ficheros con las letras de los nombres de los peques de la casa. Pongo también los stl de ellos
El impreso en capas de colores, lo he hecho introduciendo manualmente trozos por la boquilla del extrusor sin parar la cimpresión. No obstante Cura tiene un plugin para hacer cambio de filamento.

SUPER IMPORTANT UPDATE. SEE INSTRUCTIONS. 7/15/15

Spent a few hours this morning simplifying the great work done by dan0nator. This set of parts is smaller, having joined several side plates together- these will take longer to print, but the whole project is more robust and easier to put together.
I may make a system so that the hammer can be cocked and the trigger will release it in the future.

You can find a file for bullets here: [I have not printed these]
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:678671

Print one of each file- the rotating piece in front of the cylinder needs to have a little bit of the right-side corner sanded off to enable smoother rotation. Almost no one can tell once painted and assembled. Ill get a photo indicating the corner uploaded soon.
-The front plate in particular should be printed with minimal support-to-print interaction.
-Let the parts cool to room temp on the printer before taking them off. My first cylinder is so warped on the bottom I cannot properly put the whole model together and have it still rotate.
-I found that the strongest way to put this together was to friction weld around the edges and then sand smooth. Alternatively, use contact cement.

Test fit all pieces before attaching anything together. The parts around the pivot block often need a little adjustment.

DO NOT Put the two larger front sections together first. Until I get the revised parts up, you must put the center_barrel and pivot_block in between as you put them together- they will not go in afterwards!

Then connect the two large rear sections- don't forget to drop the trigger in (3mm filament or pin for correct rotation). Place cylinder on its pin and install. Install the rear half by dropping in on the back end of the cylinder pin first, then rotate the front into position under the rotation mechanism.Hammer goes where it should, using a 5mm pin/bolt. Sand the outer face of the front barrel to clean off any bumps with 80 grit. Slide the front plate on the back end of it. Set this on the front of the gun and check that everything fits. When it does, connect those two parts on as well.

Change log:
-Uploaded 7/11
-Flipped parts and re-uploaded 7/12
-Flipped front_barrel over to print without supports 7/13
-Build warning and general updates to build instructions. 7/15

remixed_from.author: chastavro
remixed_from.title: XYZ Da Vinci 1.0 X Axis Belt Tensioner

title: Davinci x belt manual tensioner - standard pulley

description.text:
The standard item has a spring and a pathetic screw to keep the tension on the belt. I found the screw would tire and then the belt would loosen under load as the spring let it go.

This is a remix of the belt tensioner http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:690090 that uses the original spring to tension the the stock pulley.

This version uses an M6 bolt through the end, it's much easier to fit - Simply loosen the bolt right off, push it all the way in, slot the idler pulley in on the belt and do the bolt up until it sounds like a bass string when plucked!

Dont use too long a bolt or it will catch on the side (the one I used is 20mm)

I did a version with a captive M6 nut, but it's much more difficult to fit, the thread ramps in the hole work just as solidly and help stop the bolt undoing.

Once I made this I actually remixed the ball bearing versions, which gives a much smoother x axis.

Print it on a raft with 100% fill.

Depending on the accuracy of your printer you will need to sand the grooves on the bottom, if only to clean up after the raft. You may also find the axle slot makes a slight ridge.

author: Spirit981

title: Feiyu Tech G3 Ultra longer Z -axis arm (More ROLL space)

description.text:
Longer Z-Axis arm for Feiyu Tech G3 Ultra 3-axi stabilizer. It allows camera to Roll more than default 45 degrees per side. By using this arm rotation can be 270 degrees on stock control cable and if you change the cable then it can be even more.

It is direct replacement for factory made arm. Control cable goes through arm so it looks much cleaner.

Comparison picture shows the difference between original and printed part. I printed it by using polycarbonite, but ABS or PLA is also fine. Please use atleast 40% infill because too thin or flexible arm makes Gimbal to oscillate and brick itself.

• Print replacement arm, use atleast 40% infill.
  • Unscrew original arm and desolder control wires from handle side.
  • Install printed arm in place and make sure it faces right direction in pan direction.
  • Replace control cable a longer one. Example old DVI cable has good quality thin wires which work nicely. You need 4 wires (GND,VCC,TX,RX). Check order before desoldering and be 100% sure that wires are correctly before switch gimbal on.
  • solder wires back in place (I removed connector from Roll -motor control board and soldered wires directly to pcb.

comments.text: This printed and fit perfectly. Thank you!

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001
For 20mm belt

This is a stop block that fits a Festool track.
It is designed to set starting and stopping points for a track saw.
An M6x12 bolt is used to tighten the block with a corresponding M6 nut trapped in a plastic adapter that goes into the aluminum extrusion.
A knob (made with the brilliant nut knob generator: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:713300) grabs the hex head of the M6 bolt, making it easy to secure and release the block.
A washer can be added to serve as a spring, between the knob and the block, but this is not mandatory.

The block has a round notch that catches the corner of the base of the saw so there are two models: a start/front block and a stop/rear block.
Typically print one of each block and two knobs plus two nuts.

2017-05-16: Added a start-front symetrical version of the stop as requested ;)

Printed in PLA at a Z resolution of 0.22mm and with a 25% infill.

Nuclear green is recommended for the knob.
Don't even think of using another color ;)

The purpose of this thing is to show how an IOS device, stand and the Vine app can be used to create a stop-motion animation station. This is a great tool for quickly sharing students work in a Makerspace or classroom. Read about the Vine Animation Station at
http://designmaketeach.com/2013/05/21/vine-animation-station/ The free Vine IOS app is available at https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/vine/id592447445?mt=8 The stand is customized for an iPhone4 in an Otterbox Commuter case.

Started by customizing thing 81117. When printed, the open design bounced when tapping to record and the angle needed tweaking. I tried to customize the stand to create a closed design with a 45 degree angle but couldn't get it quite right. I ended up drawing the profile of the design on graph paper. I then created the stand design in Inkscape using measurements from the graph paper. I resized the file to 28.225% in Inkscape. I imported into Tinkercad at 100% with height equal to 64mm which is the width of the phone in case. Example printed in blue PLA on a Printrbot LC. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HJhMMIr5zSg&rel=0

title: 2020 i3 Y Axis Cable Chain and Anchors V2

description.text:
Cable chain for 2020 Aluminum variants of the Prusa i3. I made this for my Folger Tech 2020 Prusa i3. I used ABS because the aluminum bed gets pretty hot during long ABS prints. If you only use PLA or no Heated bed, PLA is probably fine.

See instructions for printing frame mount.

UPDATE
I have revised the design a couple of times and finally have it in what I believe is the best configuration. Obviously printing a new belt mount for the Y axis belt would be best, but I didnt feel like completely taking apart my Y axis again.

The chain was confined to too small of an area and would occasionally snag on the bearing holders on the right side. So I made an offset mount , as well as the same offset + 6mm more.

The +6mm offset link goes under the bed, and the other offset goes on the frame mount. I alsmo moved my frame mount outside of the Y rods. So with the added offset the chain now clears the bearings completely and there is no more snagging and breaking links. Enjoy!
To print the frame mount, rotate it so that the clips for the chain are facing straight up. So the edge of the part touching the bed forms an L. I also printed it with a brim in ABS.

author: mel0n

title: Ultrasonic Bug Repelling Floating Waterlily - #MakeItFloat
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a floating waterlily that uses ultrasound in the 38-40kHz frequency range to repel mosquitoes and other unwanted insects from your pool or standing water, to reduce how much you have to skim and insect breeding.

Anyone who has a pool knows how much fun it can be, but also how bad it is to skim when the insects are bad. If you have a pond or standing water nearby where you like to relax, you also know how annoying insects are, and how itchy their bites can be.

So, take on the problem at the source, and reduce the number of insects that are attracted to you your pool to begin with. This also goes for ponds and standing water. Insects are repelled by higher ultrasonic frequencies, that people cannot hear, so harness this knowledge to start printing your way to a more peaceful and less itchy summer.

A single iteration was necessary to add the stabilizing ledge that drops down from the lilypad. I am still working on the design when I can, to make it better, test how well it repels insects and see how long it will last with a 9V batter to power it.

I printed both top and bottom components using the standard print settings on the Replicator 5th Gen. After printing, I sprayed both printed components with a clear water sealant to prevent water seeping through to the electronics. The assembly is designed such that the lilypad will sit just below the water surface, with the flower pedals emerging from the water.

Happy printing, and I hope this helps keep the insects away.

The Arduino nano circuit simply involves tying an ultrasonic 40kHz speaker between D3 pin and ground, then powering the circuit using a 9V battery. Please be careful using electronics around water.

Arduino Code: (Adapted from Arduino example available online)
int Hz[] = {38000, 39000, 40000};

void setup() {
}

void loop() {
for (int thisNote = 0; thisNote < 4; thisNote++) { 

tone(3, Hz[thisNote],1000);  

int pauseBetweenNotes = 1000 * 1.30;  
delay(pauseBetweenNotes);  
// stop the tone playing:  
noTone(3);

}
}

title: PRUSA I3 - Adaptative Support for the Z axis End Switch of the Sunhokey's PRUSA I3

description.text:
This Support for the Z Axis End Switch has been created in order to avoid unprecise and inadvertent changes of the position of the Z Axis End Switch.
In addition it anticipates any variation in thickness (in + or -) of the heatbed, especially in case of replacement of the original one by a glass one.

This Support can be moved up and down and firmly locked into the suitable position without the need for any modification of the printer except for the M3 bolt which is to be at least of 20mm long in replacement of the original one which is 16mm only.

It has been specifically developped for the Sunhokey PRUSA I3, even if it can fit without adapatation (or minor) to other printers which has the same kind of frame.

The file originally made with SKETCHUP is also attached for eventual adaptations.

Replacement of the original support is simple and obvious, there is not even the need to unplug the switch.

I printed it in quite a high resolution. It took few hours, but the part was very precise and could directly be used for the upgrade of the printer without any adaptation.

description.text: A customizable puzzle with a board. You can adjust the size of the stones and assign a seed to the heightmap randomizer. Make sure that each stone is quite different from the others. If it is to hard to solve you can just use 3 x 3 or even 2 x 2 stones. In the stl files the stone size is 20mm and the seed is 1. You can leave a comment when you find an interesting seed if you like.
Another socket for photomultiplier. Same contact from MOLEX than the others
Fanduct for replacing original 40mm Fan in buttom, to a focused 80mm fan, placed under the frame.

The holes need to be drilled out with a 2,5mm drill, and tapered a 3mm metric thread.

Then mount the Fan, and connect it to the mainboard instead of the 40mm fan.

Cut the cable binder holde the belt cable for the display. Mount the fanmount in the holes, where the 2 cablebinder where connected. The fanduct will now hold the belt cable.

Material used:
4x M3x30
4x M3x10
1x 80mm fan with a molex connector (or solder to the original wire)

A simple spool holder that is fully printable. Instead of the printable pivot, you may also use a 6mm or 1/4" screw and nut to make it heavier and more stable. Fits most spools available (worked on every one that I tested at least).

For one spool, print:
2x Frames
4x Pulleys
4x Pivots

title: Printrbot Play Magnetic Spool Holder Adapter

description.text:
You will need a larger printer than the play itself to print this...I may work on one that can be printed on the Play but this works for now if you have access to another larger printer. The magnets are 12mmx3mm and this requires 3 per hole so a total of 12. The plugs go in the top to cover up the remainder of the hole once it's done.

Make sure you don't have any snags in your filament as it holds firm with a a good spool but hasn't been tested on a tangled filament spool.

You will need to mark and then pre drill a hole for small screws. I used what I could find in the house that worked so I don't have a specific size.

title: Conversion Kit for Walkera G-2D Gimbal to DJI Phantom 2 Case with Mobius Cam

description.text:
Hi ...

I was looking for an lightweight and perfectly working gimbal for my Phantom 1.8 (converted Phantom 1). All these cheap china gimbals from ebay are ways to heavy and the electronics is a bit to much DIY from my point of view.

I found the Walkera G-2D gimbal on Amazon for about 70 Euro. Quite cheap and extremely lightweight. The electronic works fine and smooth. As I prefer an Mobius Cam over the GoPro Hero I created these conversion kit.

With these kit you can convert the G-2D to fit the DJI Phantom 2 Vision mount (cheap on eBay). It also has an arm which can hold the original Mobius cradle (also cheap on eBay).

It works fine an the entire construction weights less then 250g.

Enjoy ...

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I have created a personalized personal paper / note / memo holder. This will be a good addition to your office stationary. It is super easy to print and you can personalize your own memo / notes to go with it. It is also an excellent gift for your co-workers ( those that are nice to you :) ).

For the 3D print, excellent with PLA or ABS. Very easy to print, did not see any over hang.

For the note / memo / paper:
I just print the words, your name, quotes, etc. on "letter" size paper and cut it into 4 (quarter it). If you use A4 for our friends outside of US, make sure to adjust the dimensions.

Mine is just right for quartered letter size paper. You may want to make it a bit bigger for the paper to fit easier.

I have converted my Phantom 1 into an Phantom 2 Case. When you do this you have 3 challenges.

  • You need a Battery door that fits even with big LiPos. The Bay of the P2 is wide and most of the common LiPos are long.
  • You want the LED Board located somewhere visible from the back.
  • The USB port should be easy to access

This is the result. I am flying these bird now with a 3S 5600 mAh Battery. Flight time > 25 min

Enjoy ...

description.text:
"Spy boat for transfering heavy data & money across lakes" ;)
For propulsion accross a lake use fishing rod's reel on the recipient's side ;)
Very stable in water, should withstand small waves. Needs some load for stability.
Designed in FreeCAD.
Cargo of boat is shown on the last picture.
Float test : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U_3QFDis8D0
Printed in single part (deck side down).

This is my first model in Thingiverse.

UPDATE: I included the Sketchup model I designed to generate the stl. See also: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:925450

This is a model of a quadror, a folding structure created by Dror.
( http://www.quadror.com/)

The sawhorse is just one of its incarnation. It is usually made from four L-shaped parts which are glued/screwed two by two. After assembly, the folded structure may be unfolded in the form of a sawhorse. See the video: https://vimeo.com/19571732.

My challenge was to print the sawhorse as a unique folded piece. I got it!

I did not include the CAD model but you may find the sketchup files for similar sawhorses in Sketchup Warehouse:

https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com/model.html?id=554c4c12e4b87dcafe05b6214d57c7ee

and a step-by-step guide to create quadrors in:

https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com/model.html?id=91b5b70ad95fd58b3e232b593c642ba9

Remember: quadror has been patented by Dror.

This model was meant to be printed with a 0.2 layer. I used 2 shells and 30% infill but 20% should be enough.

After printing, carefully separate the two parts with a utility knife.

This is the fruits so far of my labour at making a 3D model of the most recent version of the PIP-BOY 3000: The Mk. 4. So farI've gotten the majority of the features save for a few knobs and buttons, however, upon completing this I'm likely to start on a new iteration as this being the second model I have done, I neglected to take my time to ascertain the proper dimensions. Thus it is NOT DIMENSIONALLY ACCURATE, and likely will not necessarily fit on your wrist.The important bit being that I've learned a lot in the creation of this model, and hopefully will make or contribute to a much better model in the future.

description.text: After trying a resistor heated hot-end, I got a little concerned with the tight fit in the standard mendel X axis carriage. I tried Bubak's OpenX Carriage (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6278) and I really like having an open center. In my config, I've got the dump zone on the far left and the OpenX won't let my extruder reach it. I started playing with this idea for a very lightweight carriage that would only have what I needed. Since I use mechanical endstops, it has no holes for mounting flags and is optimized for a horizontally mounted Wade's extruder. This design is narrow, light, and uses only 8 bearings. (It might be possible to fully constrain it with just 6 bearings by eliminating one on the bottom of each rail.) Since this is just an experiment, I'm marking it as a work-in-progress and I welcome comments. So far, I've only printed a couple small parts with it but it seems very light and tight. carriage3.stl is a revised version to deal with a couple problems: The belt is uncomfortably close to the screw heads on the unclamped rail. In my setup, it barely touches, but any rubbing is probably too much. This version recesses 4mm nuts in the carriage and expects a 4mm bolt instead of socket head cap screw. The direction of the bolts is reversed. The posts for mounting the extruder have been widened and are a little taller to give some additional clearance for the big Wade's gear. I added a gusseted side on each end to stiffen the carriage. I'm still planning to redesign the clamping rail to add a tensioning screw for the belt.

Print and assemble using 8 bearings, M4 Screws, nuts, and 16 M4 washers.
pinch the belt between the flat part of the clamp rail and the little clamp plate with 4 M3 screws and nuts.

title: SATA Internal to External Quick Change Box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a box that I made to make quick SSD changes to my notebook computer. This allows me to have multiple configurations that I can change over to without opening the case of my notebook. I, also, found that keeping a Master configuration allows for quick cloning to funked up hard drives. I am really pleased with the outcome. It is fully functional and looks awesome attached to my notebook with velcro. This is the first time that I used acetone to wipe a mirror finish on ABS plastic. Later, I will make a storage box for the ssd drives.

I printed on a XYZ DaVinci 1.0 @ 0.3 layer height, thick shells (3), standard speed with a fill of 25%. This allowed for much quicker print times. The largest part took 2 hr 40 min. I filed the outside surfaces with a rough file, then used a folded paper towel to wipe acetone a glossy finish. Note that this only works on ABS. Make sure that you use a needle file so that the top and bottom parts mate easily. The counter bore and hex nut relief print on the bottom of parts. I used medium fill, but wished I had used high density fill. I used #6-32 x 3/4 machine screws with hex nuts.

Wanted a sign for my daughters bedroom door so I drew one in Tinkercad.

Printed parts with a Smartrap printer.
All parts were made with PLA, 0.2 layer height, 0.3 infill and 3 layers. For the caterpillar I paused the print and swapped out the filament for black in the last 3 layers to get the black outline.
Once they were printed I used the dremel to clean up the letters and then popped them in a glass of boiling water for 20 seconds.
Once the letters were hot and soft I forced them into the holes.
A few letters needed expoxy glue to keep them in the holes.

author: romuloa123

description.text:
I recently bought TerraTiles from RAINN Studios. They are a modular wargame terrain system. They come with 1" risers for the tiles so you can make hills and elevation for your games. The tiles include rivers and roads, which look a little odd going up elevation without some visual attachment. So I created this thing so I can make rapids for the rivers, and ramps for the roads.

Size and shape of the stones, as well as the size and aspect ratio of the base are customizable. Take note that TerraTile risers are 1" tall, and the roads in that system vary from 1.7 to 2.0 inches wide.
Measurements are in millimeters. The height is set to one inch (25.4 mm) by default. If using this offline, you can set measurements using the variables inch and inches (e.g. path_width=1.8*inches;).

title: Eid Mubarak in arabic ، عيدكم مبارك

description.text:
عيدكم مبارك وكل عام وانتم بخير

Eid Mubarak or Blessed Eid is a traditional Muslim greeting reserved for use on the festivals of Eid ul-Adha and Eid ul-Fitr.
Eid means "Celebration" and refers to the occasion itself, and Mubarak means "blessed"; for example: "Eid Mubarak, sister!" "Eid Mubarak, brother!"

This is a customizeable playset that has two tracks: a square wheel track and a halfpipe wheel track. To work the square wheel track, you push the square on the humps. On the halfpipe, put the wheel on the axle and line the wheel and axle on the tracks in the halfpipe.

I wanted an awesome knife for airsoft use so I decided to try modeling Snakes CQC knife from Metal Gear Solid 3. The Strider HT-S seems to be what it was based on so I went for that.

Made in 3ds max. I didn't bother to scale correctly as Davinci's software auto scales. It Should be 8.5 inches long just keep all the proportions the same. I printed it at .1 microns with thick shells and 90% infill. This made it surprisingly very strong. I printed it in 2 halves and then super glued them together with loctite. Then I went to work with some sandpaper and my Dremel tool to get it all nice and smooth and to even out the serations. Final step, I got some green paracord and wrapped the handle as directed in this youtube video
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M0KOgbcLcmI
Gave it a very nice look. :)

Oh yeah, and the holes I made ended up not being wide enough so I had to drill them a little larger.

description.text:
This mount attaches to the G0704's existing spindle to allow an 80mm 1.5kw water cooled spindle to be mounted to the head. I use it to carve out machineable wax for silicone molds. The mount is very stiff, but I don't know if it's stiff enough for aluminum. Maybe one day I'll make it out of aluminum, but for little more than $10 worth of plastic it's fine for cutting wax. It was designed in Fusion 360.

Note: I did end up removing the center bolt from the uploaded file, in case you see the 3rd bolt in the picture. It was just too difficult to get a wrench on the middle nut, so I took it out.

It was printed on a MakerGear M2 3D printer using eSUN PETg at 248c with the heated bed at 90c using a 65% honeycomb infill from Simplify3D. PLA or ABS probably won't work well. Bolts are 5/16" x 3 1/2".

Made an air mattress plug this week.

Over a year ago we lost the plug to our air mattress. A couple weeks ago my wife says to me "why don't you print a new one?" And so I have.

Took a few tries to get the thread right for the one way valve (24mm outer diameter, 30° pitch on the thread at 13 turns per inch). I then copied that thread model, reduced the diameter it for the inside thread and then reduced it some more for the plug.

Added a rubber flapper and some O-rings.

Inflated the mattress and now we wait and see if it holds air...﻿

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4JBuUCyGZA1

Remixed from a threaded rod from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193647

Printed at 0.149mm layer height in PLA with 10% infill. Not convinced yet that the final print is 100% air tight.

O-rings and rubber sheet added to ensure seals.

comments.text: Hey buddy, nice design, saved my life but i'm just about to go camping and i just noted the valve was missing. I printed one and fitted perfect, i also used thread tape(the white one). I cutted a small piece of rubber and used a small piece of metal to make the (check valve) but didn't worked very well. Could show me some details about your "check valve".
comments.author: kabelo

comments.text: I think the success of the check valve depends on the quality of the rubber. It needs to be thick and rigid enough to hold its shape, but soft and flexible enough to form a modest seal. It does not need to be air tight - its job is not to keep the mattress inflated all night, but just long enough to fit the smaller plug in.

remixed_from.title: Filament Feed Tube Holder/Clamp for Maker Bot Replicator 2X

description.text: I modified the design by PSR4492 so that it fits my Wanhao Duplicator 4 with upgraded all metal hotends. I also made the loops that hold the filament tube a little tighter and removed the logo from it since I don't have a Replicator 2X.

I run my Flex 6300 on it's side, but didn't like the instability or the plugged cooling vents. This stand provides some stability and lifts it off the desk to provide some air flow. The slots slide into the rubber feet on the bottom of the radio.
It's an easy print with no support needed. Print 2 per radio. There is space on the front to add a callsign.

I use a lot of Arduino Nanos, and have recently rediscovered the joys of wire wrapping (refer to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:82732 if you're thinking "what the hell is that!").

This little panel supports wire wrap pins (can still get them on Ebay - poke around "long header pins"). In my case I've put 3 rows on each side - one is soldered to the Arduino Nano, the other two are arranged to support servos.

The Openscad file is included. Of course it can be modified to meet whatever need you have.

I made mine out of PLA (Migbot i3 Prusa Nozzle:215DegC Bed:45DegC). The design includes breakable "mouse ears" which you can take off if you want.

The wirewrap header pins can be glued into the holes - just a small dab is needed.

title: Traxxis T-maxx electric conversion motor and battery mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is my attempt at a printable motor and battery mount for converting a nitro Traxxis T-Maxx to be a brusheless electric. It is a work in progress but I am designing to use existing screw holes, hold a standard battery and 540 sized motor. It has slots for velcro battery straps and a 30mm fan to help keep the motor cool.

I haven't figured out what material this should be printed with. I have tested printing in ABS and PLA. PLA was nice and rigid but I am worried that a hot brushless motor may soften the plastic a bit. I will test it and see if that happens. ABS should be good for that but it is more flexible so I would recommend you print at a low layer height with thick walls and a decent amount of infill. PET may be a better material for this. Only when I test it can I report back.

UPDATE: I have tried PETG and some other filaments and still I am finding that the melting temperature is going to be too low for a hot brushless motor OR its far too flexible for the torque of such a motor. The next material I am going to try is going to be Alloy910 from Taulman3D since it claims to be high strength and able to mount directly on hot engines and even diesel engines. It prints at 250-255C so an all metal extruder is necessary.

UPDATE: I haven't done much with this lately. Nylon is tough to keep from warping and remains too flexible. Polycarbonate looks promising. ePC from eSUN seems to be easy enough to print with minimal warp, and then cures pretty rigid with enough wall thickness and infill. Additionally the fairly high glassing temperature of PC should keep it from melting when attached to a hot brushless motor. I will install a PC version into the T-Maxx soon and report back.

comments.text:
any updates?
I printed in PETG last night but just read your comments on ePC. Ever get around to trying it?
I'd like to resurrect my t-maxx. :)

comments.text: Yes I did try it. Its a bit stronger than the PETG and less flex. It does require as much infill as you can comfortably print and at least 4 walls thick to get enough rigidity. I think I had it at 70% infill. Its a lot and I still haven't installed it in the T-maxx.

author: brentarogers

description.text:
This work in progress has been a long term goal of mine, at least in the past year and a half that I have been involved in 3D printing. The recent release of electrically conductive filament has enabled some amazing circuitry creations to say the least.

What I have done is create a breadboard with a 3D printed conductive node. We know that we can print the nonconductive part of a breadboard, it's the electrical grabbers underneath that grab the wires that have resisted replacement, and this morning (July 11 2015) I realized that a simple wedge shape could replace the grabbers!

So I made a quick OpenSCAD model of a wedge that would fit and got some OK results. Each resistor had a 500 Ohm Resistance to a central low resistance node - makes sense I guess.

Then I printed a second wedge that fit better and was thinner and got very low resistance for the node for some unknown reason. Later this node opened up though, so I think it was loose.

In fact, I think what is needed is not the friction fit that the wedge alone provides; rather we should put some simple spring-loaded mechanism in the print of the breadboard itself to hold the sides of the wires against the conduictive wedge or rectangle.

Well, it's an open source community and this is a well-wanted item so I figure someone if not me will figure out something that works as well as this only better lol.

Les
p.s. see the following link for a full working breadboard! :)
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/electronics-breadboard

title: George R. R. Martin's Cyvasse (unofficial game)

description.text: This is my attempt to translate the chess-like game featured in George R. R. Martin's A Song of Ice and Fire novels (Game of Thrones). Being a huge fan of the man and his work, I wanted to try and give his game the best translation I could. Working with my good friend (and studious Martin scholar) Nate Stephens, I adapted the game to include everything mentioned in the book into a rules set I found believable for a game made during the emulated time period, while also keeping the games in mind that Martin has mentioned as inspiration during interviews. So, Let me know if you get to printing/playing it, and if you have any suggestions for rules adjustments, variants, etc, post in the comments below and let's get a dialogue going. The rules PDF is with the other downloads, and its a light read (2 pages). Game on! Oh, and my version of Cyvasse is now available in the Steam Workshops if you have Tabletop Simulator (and you should have that): http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=383019836&tscn=1422489650

With the current rules configurations, you'll need to print the following: Each side (Onyx and Alabaster) has
Rabble x3, Spearmen x3, Crossbowmen x3, Light Horses x3,
Heavy Horses x2, Elephants x2, Catapult x1, Trebuchet x1,
Dragon x1, King x1, Keep x1 All of the pieces are grouped to reflect the distribution, so you only need to print each STL once. Of course, if you'e feeling brave, you can print the full plate, That has all the pieces one side will need. In addition, you'll need 6 mountains (three per player), four board sections (two per player), a pair of screen braces (both are in the same STL) and the two halves of the screen. I printed mine in black ABS and painted the pieces with acrylic model paints though the pieces would be great printed in black and white ABS, and wouldn't really require painting (that's just how I roll). I also painted the board in a checker-pattern. It wasn't necessary, but it makes movements (especially diagonal ones) a little easier to track.

comments.text: I haven't played the game, but a middle ground might be changing the crossbowman's special movement rule to something like "May instead jump to an unoccupied forest tile within 3 tiles (counting diagonally as well)." This gives the crossbowman a huge reach (basically a whole quarter of the board, bypassing mountains, keeps, pieces, etc), but means you have to get your crossbowman with range of your enemies keep before the "punch+crossbowman" becomes a threat. You can't just keep it off in the corner somewhere, nice and safe, and your opponent has two angles of defence - protect his keep, or take out the crossbowman.

comments.text:
This is very well done. The pieces are wonderful. I have some ideas about the rules, but having not played it yet I'll just mention one, since it's the only one that affects the form of the pieces. The 'gameofcyvasse' website has rules which allow the dragons to stop on a mountain - which seems reasonable - if the dragon piece had a suitable concavity on the bottom then it could be perched on there. At least then you have the option of allowing a dragon on a mountain.
I wouldn't be too concerned about the three colors - especially that they could imply a hex board. Another way to have 3 colors is to use one pair of colors on the black side, and another pair on the white side - if there were some rules that applied differently according to which side of the board you were on, that would be helpful.
I like that the keep can hold a piece - perhaps that's where you put the king when at home - or perhaps the projectile attacks - like spearmen, crossbow, trebuchet - can be there. Of course such a piece is midway between ranks which may create some issues.

It wouldn;t be much of a stretch to then say that movements that would go through water tiles stop there, or even that orthogonal moves are stopped in blue and diagonal moves aren't (giving further special power to the dragon, trebuchet, and catapult without having to write in more "special effects). I'd have to play it out that way, but I'm all for giving it a shot. It really only complicates things by one additional step, and for me, minimizing the the complication, maximizing the fun dynamism of play, and sticking to the information given in the books are three completely equal parts of the goal with this thing.

comments.text: I don't this is inconsistent with the idea that all of those moves are single pieces - if you have a piece representing a group of crossbowmen or spearmen, etc. And the term 'horse', is, believe, often used as a collective term to describe a group of mounted soldiers.
comments.author: hyla

comments.text: Yeah, and there's lots of ways to take that. One is that each piece represents any number of troops. So, a single spearman would technically be 10s to 100s of spearmen (pretty common terms for war games and board games alike). The reason I'm led to believe that there are multiples of pieces are the entries that elude to there being so, like "putting elephants in the mountain passes." While "elephants" could be pluralized to represent one piece, the mountain passes wouldn't be, saying that a common strategy is to place multiple mountains in front of your keep and put elephants between them. Because of this, we know there are multiple elephant pieces, and if the elephants are one of the most powerful pieces (something else we know from the texts), then it stand to reason that there are multiples of the lesser pieces.
comments.author: hyla

comments.author: dutchmogul

comments.text: Oh yeah, gotta watch out for those light horses! They're so tricky, but we've started to adapt to their strategy in our games. Most of the time we play with the king in the keep, though we all have different strategies for guarding our backs. Some of my friends put their mountains in a line back there, though I tend to put "lesser" pieces back there (like conscripts and spearmen) and maybe an elephant (seeing as they're all but invulnerable when they're well supported) as light horse deterrent. Nobody wants to lose a light horse to take a lesser piece. I've seen lots of different strategies though.

These are Chinese Floating Lantern. It is fun to google and learn the history of floating lanterns in many cultures. Science and math insure the buoyancy of the float. It is also fun to learn the meaning of the riddles and to learn the art of calligraphy. #MakeItFloat

Update 7/17/15
The Science behind the lantern.

Buoyancy and Archimedes

http://www.sciencekids.co.nz/videos/physics.html

The Science behind this project is more about light and how it diffuses in the different shades. It is also a great time to talk about the different frequencies of light and that is why we get different colors observable from each shade. The graphic above is courtesy of http://www.livescience.com/32559-why-do-we-see-in-color.html

The science of light is critical to research in eye health. Even the Mantis Shrimp gets to take part.

http://www.gizmag.com/mantis-shrimp-eyes-cancer-camera/34049/

I think social science is also a key category in this build. The art and history of Chinese Calligraphy is amazing and very fun to learn about.

http://afe.easia.columbia.edu/special/china_1000bce_calligraphy.htm

Update 7/15/15
I have added a V2 of the base that is rounder and may be a little easier for some to print. If you print the base at 10% infill it is strong enough and floats well. It is better to have 3 perimeters to make sure that it is watertight.

Both the first and second versions of the base should print fine with a well tuned printer. I printed the base at 3 layers with 10% infill to give it plenty of buoyancy.

The shade should be printed with a single layer. So even light opaque filaments should let some light through. It is best if you could use a transparent or translucent pla.

The tealights can be purchased from Amazon
http://www.amazon.com/White-Submersible-Light-Wedding-Centerpieces-set/dp/B005W4P8ME/ref=sr_1_6?s=home-garden&ie=UTF8&qid=1437315011&sr=1-6&keywords=floating+tea+lights

comments.text: The prints are stable and ready
